author: CNN Newsource
title: Group of Palestinian-Americans skip Blinken meeting over Biden admin‚Äôs support for Israel‚Äôs offensive in Gaza
text: Group of Palestinian-Americans skip Blinken meeting over Biden admin‚Äôs support for Israel‚Äôs offensive in Gaza By Jennifer Hansler, and Khalil Abdallah, CNN (CNN) ‚Äî A number of Palestinian-Americans refused to attend a roundtable meeting with US Secretary of State Antony Blinken on Thursday to discuss the [situation in Gaza](https://www.cnn.com/world/middleeast/israel) in protest against the Biden administration‚Äôs ongoing support for Israel‚Äôs offensive in the war-torn strip ‚Äì a military campaign that has exacted a massive humanitarian toll. ‚ÄúWe do not know what more Secretary Blinken or President (Joe) Biden need to hear or see to compel them to end their complicity in this genocide,‚Äù several of those who rejected the invitation said in a press statement distributed by the non-profit Institute for Middle East Understanding (IMEU). ‚ÄúThey show us every day whose lives they value and whose lives they consider disposable. We will not be attending this discussion which can only amount to a box-ticking exercise. Our families, our community and all Palestinians deserve better,‚Äù the signatories wrote. ‚ÄúThere is one thing that we, our community and countless others around the US and the world, including American unions representing nearly 8 million workers and at least 47 US cities, have been asking of this administration: to demand a permanent ceasefire to save Palestinians lives and stop the destruction of Gaza,‚Äù they wrote. ‚ÄúA meeting of this nature at this moment in time is insulting and performative.‚Äù Blinken and other members of the Biden administration have [called on Israel to do more to protect civilian](https://www.cnn.com/2024/01/07/politics/blinken-israel-middle-east-tensions/index.html)s and allow more humanitarian aid into Gaza. The officials, however, have continually rejected the idea of a ceasefire, instead advocating for ‚Äúhumanitarian pauses.‚Äù Thursday‚Äôs meeting with Blinken comes amid continued outrage from many progressive Democrats, Muslim and younger voters about the administration‚Äôs handling of Gaza ‚Äì opposition that poses a growing political problem for Biden. The refusal of several invitees to attend underscores the immense anger felt by many in the United States ‚Äì including some within the federal government ‚Äì over the toll from the conflict, which was launched following [Hamas‚Äô brutal attack](https://www.cnn.com/2023/10/09/middleeast/hamas-attack-strategy-israel-mime-intl/index.html) on Israel on October 7. More than 26,000 have been killed, hundreds of thousands have been displaced, and Gaza is on the brink of famine. More than 200 Israeli soldiers have been killed in the offensive. Six people did attend the meeting, a source familiar told CNN, and those who attended felt conflicted about doing so, but felt they should take advantage of the opportunity to speak to the need for urgent change in US policy toward Gaza. ‚ÄòSoul-searching‚Äô One of the invitees to the roundtable, Dr. Tariq Haddad, said in an intensely personal, 12-page letter to Blinken that he initially intended to go to the meeting. However, ‚Äúafter a lot of soul-searching I have decided that I cannot in good conscience meet with you today knowing this administration‚Äôs policies have been responsible for the death of over 80 of my family members including dozens of children, the suffering of hundreds of my remaining family, the famine my family is currently subjected to and the destruction of all my family‚Äôs homes,‚Äù Haddad wrote in the letter. ‚ÄúThe more I thought about this meeting, the more I could not emotionally bring myself to look you in the eyes, Secretary Blinken, knowing you and President Biden have knowingly contributed to the suffering and murder of so many of my family, the homelessness and dispossession of 2 million Gazans, and the famine that has befallen my remaining family members,‚Äù Haddad said. ‚ÄúHow does one meet for what I was told would be 3 minutes, with a person you hold responsible for not just the killing of your child, but rather the murder of over 80 of your family members?‚Äù he asked in his letter. ‚ÄúHow do I look you in the eyes knowing you couldn‚Äôt even do the basic minimum like calling for a ceasefire to end the suffering and carnage, and even worse, are cutting off humanitarian assistance to 2 million people going through a famine of historic proportions,‚Äù he wrote, appearing to reference the suspension of US aid to the UN‚Äôs main relief agency in Gaza, UNRWA. ‚ÄúMy family are subsisting on animal feed, Secretary Blinken, because of your policies,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúYou could have called for a cease-fire at any point in the past four months and ended all this suffering and death, and you have not. You could have used your diplomatic pressure to end the suffering, and you chose not to. You could have recognized that shutting off aid to an area that is experiencing the worst famine and human rights disaster in modern history is unethical, yet you chose not to. This is why it is very difficult emotionally for me to meet you today, to somehow normalize a meeting with an administration that continues day after day to cause so much suffering and death with their policies,‚Äù he wrote. Haddad urged Blinken to call for an immediate ceasefire, ‚Äúend the continued transfer of US military reserve equipment to the Israeli military to stop further murder,‚Äù ‚Äúcall for an immediate withdrawal out of Gaza and equality for the Palestinian people,‚Äù and a ‚Äúcall for an end to the Israeli occupation, for equal rights, freedoms, and laws in this land regardless of one‚Äôs religion, ethnicity, or background.‚Äù Haddad told CNN that the letter ‚Äì in which he also included photos of some of his relatives who have been killed ‚Äì was going to be handed directly to Blinken at Thursday‚Äôs meeting. The source familiar with the meeting said some parts of it were read out loud to the top US diplomat during the hour-and-a-half long session at the State Department. That source said Blinken seemed engaged, but largely stuck to talking points in his remarks. At a briefing Thursday, State Department spokesperson Matt Miller confirmed that Blinken met with ‚Äúa number of leaders in the Palestinian-American community.‚Äù ‚ÄúIt was the latest in a series of meetings that the Secretary has had with individuals and organizations both within the department and from outside the department that hold a wide range of views across the ideological and political spectrum,‚Äù Miller said. ‚ÄúHe has held these meetings because he thinks it‚Äôs important to hear directly from individuals as I said, both inside the State Department and outside the State Department.‚Äù ‚ÄúHe finds that process to be constructive. It informs his thinking. It helps him, he believes, shape policy in the best way possible,‚Äù he said. Public opposition And while Blinken was quietly confronted behind closed doors about the administration‚Äôs policy toward Gaza on Thursday, members of the administration, including Blinken, have also faced public displays of opposition. A number of protesters have camped in front of Blinken‚Äôs house since last Friday to try to pressure a change in policy. At a public speech on Tuesday, Samantha Power, head of the US Agency for International Development (USAID) was twice confronted about the administration‚Äôs position toward Gaza. One questioner, who identified herself as a USAID contractor, asked Power about the loss of the US‚Äô ability ‚Äúto be moral leaders‚Äù due to the ‚ÄúUS funded genocide in Gaza.‚Äù Another person interrupted her speech to raise the massive humanitarian toll. ‚ÄúIt is a devastating situation where not enough resources are getting in, via the Rafah crossing or the Kerem Shalom crossing,‚Äù Power said. ‚ÄúAnd we are working 24/7 to try to dramatically expand the flow of food, medicine, shelter ‚Äì I mean, so much is needed. But, you know, you have families right now that are living in unimaginable conditions.‚Äù ‚ÄúIn addition, of course, the greatest loss of life has come from the war itself and from the bombing, and more than 25,000 civilians have been killed. There is not a single call that President Biden makes, or engagement that anybody in the Biden administration does, that doesn‚Äôt put the importance of civilian protection and international humanitarian law, at the top of the conversation,‚Äù she said. A USAID spokesperson said that ‚Äúsince the start of this conflict, Administrator Power and other Agency leadership have held numerous engagements with staff in the US and at USAID Missions around the world to discuss the US and USAID response to the conflict, offer appreciation for their work, and hear a range of perspectives and concerns.‚Äù The-CNN-Wire ‚Ñ¢ & ¬© 2024 Cable News Network, Inc., a Warner Bros. Discovery Company. All rights reserved.

title: Pais protestam por escola n√£o renovar matr√≠cula de alunos autistas em Barcelos - 24 Not√≠cias
text:
Pais protestam por escola n√£o renovar matr√≠cula de alunos autistas em Barcelos Barcelos, Braga, 26 jun 2025 (Lusa) - Duas dezenas de pais manifestaram-se hoje junto ao Agrupamento de Escolas Vale do Tamel, em Barcelos, contra a decis√£o do diretor de n√£o permitir a renova√ß√£o de matr√≠cula no 12.¬∫ ano de dois alunos com autismo.
Em causa est√£o alunos com 18 e 19 anos que, por falta de respostas sociais na regi√£o, v√£o ter de ficar em casa a partir de agora e, como n√£o podem ficar sozinhos, um dos progenitores vai ter de deixar o trabalho para cuidar deles.
"√â de lamentar a enorme falta de sensibilidade do diretor do agrupamento, que, ainda por cima, √© professor de Religi√£o e Moral", disse Sofia Cruz, m√£e do aluno com 19 anos.
Sofia Cruz disse que o filho est√° h√° cinco anos inscrito para uma vaga de num centro de atividades e capacita√ß√£o para a inclus√£o (CACI).
"Contava que a escola deixasse o meu filho ficar mais um ano, mas o diretor disse-me que n√£o h√° a m√≠nima hip√≥tese, que a escola n√£o √© a resposta para estas situa√ß√µes e que n√£o quer abrir precedentes. Mas a verdade √© que j√° houve um precedente", referiu.
O porta-voz do movimento Pais em Luta, Jorge Castro, sublinhou que a decis√£o do diretor √© "discriminat√≥ria", j√° que, numa escola do concelho vizinho de Esposende, alunos nas mesmas circunst√¢ncias conseguiram que lhes fosse garantida a renova√ß√£o de matr√≠cula no 12.¬∫ ano, j√° pela quarta vez consecutiva.
"Os nossos filhos n√£o s√£o 'precedentes', s√£o seres humanos com necessidades especiais, e os recursos aparecem quando a necessidade assim o exige", apontou.
Em 12 de junho, os pais de crian√ßas e jovens manifestaram-se frente √† Seguran√ßa Social de Braga contra a falta de vagas em CACI na regi√£o.
Jorge Castro entrou mesmo em greve de fome, um protesto que acabaria por terminar j√° √† noite, depois de o Instituto da Seguran√ßa Social ter deixado a garantia de cria√ß√£o de 60 vagas em Esposende, num "curto espa√ßo de tempo, entre seis meses a um ano".
"Por um ano, se houvesse o m√≠nimo de sensibilidade, o Agrupamento de Escolas Vale do Tamel n√£o podia acolher mais dois alunos?", criticou, sublinhando ser "lament√°vel" que o Estado "atire para o desemprego pais trabalhadores, para cuidar dos seus filhos com necessidades especiais".
Os pais presentes na manifesta√ß√£o empunhavam cartazes com frases como "Dignidade para os nossos filhos", "Somos pais, queremos trabalhar", "A defici√™ncia n√£o se esconde" e "Respeito pelo cidad√£o portador de defici√™ncia".
O diretor do agrupamento, Al√≠pio Barbosa, manifestou-se indispon√≠vel para falar aos jornalistas.
VCP // JAP
Lusa/Fim
Em destaque

author: Linda F Hersey
title: Health data of millions of veterans might have been leaked in cyberattack of VA vendor | Stars and Stripes
text: Fifteen million veterans were notified by the Department of Veterans Affairs this week that a cybersecurity breach involving one of its vendors might have exposed their private health care information. Change Healthcare, which processes payments for VA patients, informed the agency that a ‚Äúsubstantial proportion of people in America could have had some information leaked,‚Äù VA Secretary Denis McDonough said Thursday during his monthly news conference. ‚ÄúWe are pushing for more information. We will move quickly to provide full support and protect veteran data. We are not waiting for that confirmation,‚Äù he said. Change Healthcare is the nation‚Äôs largest payment processor for health care services. Clinics, pharmacies and community providers submit patient claims via a portal or directly to Change Healthcare, which processes them for payment. United HealthGroup, parent company of Change Healthcare, described the breach as a ‚Äúmalicious criminal cyberattack‚Äù and issued a statement this week following an audit of the company‚Äôs systems. ‚ÄúBased on initial targeted data sampling to date, the company has found files containing protected health information or personally identifiable information, which could cover a substantial proportion of people in America,‚Äù the company said. But there is no evidence that ‚Äúdoctors‚Äô charts‚Äù or patients‚Äô ‚Äúfull medical histories‚Äù were transferred from Change Healthcare systems. The attackers were identified as a criminal organization that deployed a ransomware attack against United HealthGroup. The VA was first notified in February of a cybersecurity incident at Change Healthcare that delayed payment processing and some prescription orders for veterans using VA health services, McDonough said. ‚ÄúThe incident initially impacted a good number of our IT functions, community care payment processes among them. We‚Äôve now restored many of those capabilities, and we‚Äôre working to get 100% of them up and going,‚Äù he said. McDonough said there was no impact on patient care. He also said the VA has remained focused on restoring systems and strengthening firewalls to protect veteran data. Veterans have been notified by email that they are eligible to sign up for two years of free credit monitoring paid for by Change Healthcare, McDonough said. The VA also is providing veterans with links to resources for preventing online identity theft and fraud. McDonough said as Change Healthcare provides more information on the scope of the breach, the VA will inform Congress, veterans service organizations and veterans. ‚ÄúWe are committed to transparency and moving quickly to provide full support for protecting veterans and their data,‚Äù he said.

author: Minh Le
title: Musk's attorney urges OpenAI auction: sources
text:
Elon Musk‚Äôs attorney, Marc Toberoff, has urged attorneys general in California and Delaware to push OpenAI to auction off a significant stake in the company, according to sources familiar with the matter.
This request aims to assess the fair value of OpenAI‚Äôs charitable assets as the company restructures to separate its for-profit business and non-profit operations.
Toberoff emphasized the need for competitive bidding to protect the public‚Äôs interest in OpenAI‚Äôs charitable assets.
This request follows OpenAI‚Äôs move to form a public benefit corporation to support fundraising efforts.
A court decision on Musk‚Äôs request for a preliminary injunction is expected later this month.
Recent OpenAI developments Timeline 06-Jan-2025 üìâ OpenAI forecasts $5b loss as $200 ChatGPT Pro struggles OpenAI CEO announces $5B loss projections for 2024 Seeking funding, restructuring, and higher subscription fees 28-Dec-2024 üîÑ OpenAI plans to shift to public benefit corporation OpenAI shifts to public benefit corporation. Criticism and lawsuit amid funding needs rise. 24-Dec-2024 ü§ñ OpenAI‚Äôs new model shows favorable results, but faces high costs OpenAI launches o3 model, scoring 88% on ARC-AGI. New test-time scaling increases costs over $10,000/task. 22-Dec-2024 üöÄ OpenAI unveils AI model for advanced reasoning OpenAI unveils new model o3 for complex reasoning Safety measures in place with researcher evaluations 17-Dec-2024 üöÄ OpenAI expands ChatGPT with free AI search AI search engine now available to all ChatGPT users Improved mobile experience with detailed search results 15-Dec-2024 üÜï OpenAI launches ‚ÄòProjects‚Äô feature for task organization OpenAI launches ‚ÄòProjects‚Äô feature for ChatGPT Currently for Plus, Pro, Teams; Edu access in 2024

author: Peggy Heuer
title: Jim Novotny
text:
James ‚ÄúJim‚Äù Novotny, age 72, of Roseau, MN, passed away Tuesday, January 16, 2024, at his home. A Celebration of Life will be held on Saturday, March 2nd, 2024, at the VFW Post #9317 in Mantador, ND at 3pm. Inurnment will be held at a later date at St. Paul Lutheran Cemetery near Mooreton, ND. Arrangements have been entrusted to Helgeson Funeral Home in Roseau, MN
James Charles Novotny was born October 11, 1951, to James and Helen (Hejtmanek) in Breckenridge, MN. He grew up on a family farm in Mandator, ND and attended grade school in Mantador, ND, graduating from high school in Hankinson, ND in 1969. Jim enrolled at NDSCS in Wahpeton, ND where he graduated in 1972 with an Associate of Science in Architectural Drafting.
Jim was united in marriage to Victoria (Vicki) Lynn Johnson on October 29, 1972, at Bethel Lutheran Church in Wahpeton, ND. Shortly after as a member of the US Army, Jim was assigned to Nuremberg, Germany where he and Vicki resided for 5 years. In 1977 Jim and Vicki moved from Germany to Breckenridge, MN where they celebrated the birth of their first daughter Christina Lynn. In the winter of 1979 Jim and Vicki moved to Roseau, MN, where Jim and Vicki welcomed two more children, Amanda Kay in 1980 and Seth Gordon in 1983.
Jim worked as the service manager for both Roseau Farm Service and Roseau Diesel before taking the leap into self-employment in 1988. Novotny‚Äôs Overhead Doors became recognized in the Roseau Community, especially when his ‚Äúmilk‚Äù van dropped his three children off at school. Jim was a reliable, honest, and all-around asset to the community he called home. Jim‚Äôs son Seth has taken on the legacy that Jim left and is operating Novotny‚Äôs Overhead Doors still today in Roseau, MN.
After leaving the Army Jim enrolled in the Roseau Army Reserve and was a Staff Sargent for more than 20 years. In addition to serving his country, Jim joined the Roseau Volunteer Fire Department and spent many years serving his community.
Jim and Vicki built a lovely home on 3rd Ave, that was bustling with kids, friends, family, and a cat named Bonkers who, legend has it, was named even before ‚ÄúBonkers‚Äù was a candy.
Everyone belonged at the Novotny‚Äôs house, Jim and Vicki made sure of it. In 2001 Jim and Vicki lovingly welcomed Jamie Everett, followed by Ryan Thorson in 2008, and later Brittany Nosbusch.
When Jim‚Äôs kids were not making trouble in the early years, they were living life and making Jim and Vicki proud. This applied to the next generation as well. Jim and Vicki could not be prouder of their three beautiful granddaughters, Emma, Hannah, and Ava Everett.
Jim is preceded in death by his parents Helen and James Novotny, his beloved wife, Victoria and brother-in-law Gary Gabbert. Jim is survived by his children Christina (Jamie) Everett of Fargo, ND, Amanda (Ryan) Thorson of Ottertail, MN and Seth (Brittany) Novotny of Roseau, MN. As well as his granddaughters Emma Everett (Brandon Miller), Hannah Everett, and Ava Everett all of Fargo, ND. Jim is also survived by his brother Clifford (Marie) Novotny, and his sisters Shirley (Art) Heley and Dorothy Gabbert.
Guestbook URL: https://www.helgesonfuneralhome.com/obituary/JamesJim-Novotny
